questions.text: In certain regions, children frequently exhibit clinical symptoms of a particular endemic disease, while most adults remain asymptomatic carriers due to long-term exposure and immunity. This pattern of disease distribution is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Holoendemic is a term used to describe a high level of infection beginning early in life and affecting most of the child population, leading to a state of equilibrium such that the adult population shows evidence of the disease much less commonly than do the children.
  • E.g.: Malaria in certain African regions - nearly all individuals are infected early in life, but only young children suffer severe illness.

Explanation of other options:

Hyperendemic (Option A): The term hyperendemic expresses that the disease is constantly present at a high incidence and/or prevalence rate and affects all age groups equally.

Syndemic (Option B): Syndemic refers to the synergistic interaction between two or more coexisting diseases or health conditions within a population.

Pandemic (Option C): (An epidemic occurring over a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, and usually affecting a large number of people.

questions.text: Match the disease occurrence terms with their correct definitions:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sporadic:

  • The word sporadic means scattered about.
  • The cases occur irregularly, haphazardly from time to time, and generally infrequently.
  • The cases are so few and separated widely in space and time that they show little or no connection with each other, nor a recognisable common source of infection.
  • g.: herpes-zoster and meningococcal meningitis.

Pandemic:

  • A pandemic refers to the widespread occurrence of a disease across multiple countries or continents, affecting a large proportion of the global population.
  • Characteristics of an infectious agent influencing the causation of a pandemic include that the agent must be able:
    • to infect humans
    • to cause disease in humans
    • to spread easily from human to human
  • Examples are influenza pandemics and cholera pandemics.

Endemic:

  • Endemic refers to the constant presence of a disease within a specific geographic area or population group.
  • Endemic diseases persistently occur at a relatively stable level within their defined area or group, without necessarily spreading beyond those boundaries.

Epidemic:

  • An epidemic refers to the occurrence of cases of a disease, specific health behaviour, or event in a defined community or region that is more than the normal expected frequency.
  • Epidemicity is thus relative to the usual frequency of the disease in the same area, among the specified population, at the same season of the year.

questions.text: In the context of communicable diseases, what term is used for the first case that comes to the attention of health authorities or a physician?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The first case of a communicable disease that comes to the notice of a physician is referred to as the index case

  • The index case is the first documented case of a particular disease within a population, community, or outbreak setting that comes to the attention of healthcare providers.
  • Identifying the index case is crucial in epidemiology as it helps trace the origin and spread of the disease, initiate control measures, and prevent further transmission.
  • An index case is not always the primary case.

Explanation of other options:

Primary case (Option A): A primary case refers to the first case of a communicable disease introduced into the population unit that is being studied.

Secondary case (Option C): A secondary case is a case that arises from exposure to an existing case, typically as a result of transmission of the infectious agent from the primary case.

Suspect case (Option D): A suspect case is an individual or a group of individuals who has all of the signs and symptoms of a disease or condition, yet has not been diagnosed as having the disease or had the cause of the symptoms connected to the suspected pathogen. Suspect cases require further investigation, testing, or evaluation to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: All of the following states are associated with shedding of infectious organisms except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In latent infection, the infectious organism remains dormant or inactive within the host's body.
  • During this period, the individual does not shed the infectious organism, as it is not actively replicating or causing symptoms.
  • However, under certain conditions, such as immune system weakening or reactivation of the latent infection, the individual may become capable of shedding the organism and transmitting the infection to others.
  • Nevertheless, during the latent phase, the individual is not actively shedding the organism, distinguishing it from the other options.

Explanation of other options:

Convalescent carrier state (Option B): Convalescent carrier state refers to individuals who have recovered from the acute illness but continue to shed the infectious organism during the recovery period. Although they may no longer show symptoms, they remain capable of transmitting the infection to others.

Subclinical infection (Option C): Subclinical infection refers to an infection that does not cause overt clinical symptoms or signs but may still result in shedding of the infectious organism. Individuals with subclinical infections can unknowingly spread the infection to others.

Healthy carrier state (Option D): Healthy carriers are individuals who harbour and shed infectious organisms without exhibiting any signs or symptoms of disease. They can act as reservoirs of infection and transmit the pathogen to others.

choices.text: A convalescent carrier continues to shed pathogens even after clinical recovery
Healthy carriers show no symptoms but can still transmit the infection
Chronic carriers shed the pathogen for a prolonged or indefinite period
Pseudo-carriers are highly infectious and play a major role in disease transmission

questions.text: All of the following statements about carriers of infectious diseases are true except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic carriers are individuals who continue to harbour and shed infectious agents for an indefinite or prolonged period, often for years or even a lifetime.

  • A carrier is defined as an infected person or animal that harbours a specific infectious agent in the absence of discernible clinical disease and serves as a potential source of infection for others.
  • Carriers are usually less infectious than cases but more dangerous epidemiologically because they remain undetected, live normally in the community, and can spread infection widely over a longer period.

Carriers may be classified as below:

Based on type:

  • Incubatory carriers: Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agent during the incubation period of the disease. That is, they are capable of infecting others before the onset of illness.

E.g.: Measles, mumps, polio, pertussis, influenza, diphtheria, hepatitis A

  • Convalescent carriers: Includes those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence.

E.g.: Typhoid, dysentery, cholera, diphtheria, pertussis

  • Healthy carriers: They are victims of subclinical infection who have developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease, but are nevertheless shedding the disease agent.

E.g.: Polio, cholera, meningococcal meningitis.

Based on duration:

  • Temporary carriers: Temporary carriers are those who shed the infectious agent for short periods of time. In this category may be included the incubatory, convalescent and healthy carriers.
  • Chronic carriers: A chronic carrier is one who excretes the infectious agent for indefinite periods. They are far more important sources of infection than cases.

E.g.: typhoid, hepatitis B, dysentery, malaria, gonorrhoea

Pseudo-carriers: Carriers of avirulent organisms are called pseudo-carriers. Pseudo-carriers are not important epidemiologically.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is known to exhibit vertical transmission?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vertical or transplacental transmission refers to the transmission of a disease from a mother to her offspring during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding.
  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can be transmitted vertically from mother to baby during childbirth, especially if the mother has active genital herpes lesions at the time of delivery.
  • The virus can be shed from the genital tract and infect the newborn during passage through the birth canal.
  • This can result in neonatal herpes, which can cause severe complications or even death in newborns.

Diseases with Vertical Transmission:

  • TORCH infections
  • Varicella
  • Syphillis
  • Hepatitis B
  • Coxsackie B
  • HIV

Explanation of other options:

Leprosy (Option B): Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is primarily transmitted through prolonged close contact with untreated individuals who have leprosy. It is not typically transmitted vertically from mother to child during pregnancy or childbirth.

Tetanus (Option C): Tetanus is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani, which is commonly found in soil, dust, and animal faeces. Tetanus is acquired through the contamination of wounds or cuts with spores of the bacterium, rather than through vertical transmission from mother to child.

Whooping cough (Option D): Whooping cough, or pertussis, is caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis. It is primarily transmitted through respiratory droplets from the coughing or sneezing of infected individuals. It is not transmitted vertically from mother to child during pregnancy or childbirth.

choices.text: Infection -Entry and multiplication of an infectious agent within the host body
Contamination -Presence of infectious agents on inanimate objects or body surfaces
Infestation -Lodgement and reproduction of arthropods on the surface of the body or clothing
Contagion -Entry of arthropods into the bloodstream, causing infection

questions.text: All of the following terms are correctly matched with their definitions except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Contagion refers to the transmission or spread of a disease from one person to another, typically through direct or indirect contact.
  • It encompasses both direct and indirect modes of transmission, including respiratory droplets, saliva, blood, and other bodily fluids.
  • Contagion is a key factor in the epidemiology of infectious diseases and plays a crucial role in understanding and controlling disease outbreaks.

Explanation of other options:

Infection - Entry and multiplication of an infectious agent within the host body (Option A): Infection refers to the entry and development or multiplication of pathogenic microorganisms within the body of a host organism. It also implies that the body responds in some way to defend itself against the invader, either in the form of an immune response (evidence of this may not be readily available) or disease.

Contamination - Presence of infectious agents on inanimate objects or body surfaces (Option B): Contamination refers to the presence or introduction of harmful or undesirable substances, such as pathogens or pollutants, into an environment or onto surfaces.

Infestation - Lodgement and reproduction of arthropods on the surface of the body or clothing (Option C): Infestation specifically refers to the lodgement, development and reproduction of arthropods on the surface of the body or in the clothing. This term is commonly used to describe conditions caused by organisms such as lice, mites, fleas, or ticks.

questions.text: Malaria is transmitted through mosquitoes by which type of biological transmission?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Malaria, caused by Plasmodium parasites and transmitted by mosquitoes, is a classic example of cyclopropagative biological transmission.
  • In this type of transmission, the infectious agent undergoes both multiplication and development within the vector.
  • Inside the mosquito, Plasmodium completes complex stages, including the sporogony (an asexual reproduction) process that generates infectious sporozoites. These sporozoites are then transmitted to humans during a subsequent blood meal.

Biological transmission: In biological transmission, the infectious agent undergoes replication, development, or both within the vector and requires an incubation period before the vector becomes capable of transmitting the disease.

Types of Biological transmission:

  • Propagative: The infectious agent merely multiplies in a vector, but no change in form occurs.

Example: Plague bacilli in rat fleas, Arboviruses like dengue and Zika

  • Cyclo-propagative: The infectious agent multiplies and undergoes development inside the vector.

Example: Malaria parasites in mosquitoes

  • Cyclo-developmental: The disease agent undergoes only development but no multiplication.

Example: Microfilaria in a mosquito.

  • Transovarial transmission: The infectious agent is transmitted vertically from the infected female to her progeny in the vector.

Example: Rickettsia in ticks

  • Transstadial transmission: Transmission of the disease agent from one stage of the life cycle to another, as nymph to adult.

Example: Borrelia in ticks (Lyme disease)

choices.text: Transovarial transmission - Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks
Propagative - Yersinia pestis in rat fleas

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of biological transmission types and examples is incorrectly
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Borrelia burgdorferi causative agent of Lyme disease, is transmitted via transstadial transmission in ticks, not transovarial.
  • Transstadial transmission refers to the transmission of a pathogen from one life stage of a vector to the next, such as from larva to nymph to adult.
  • Transovarial transmission occurs when an infected female vector passes the pathogen to her offspring through her eggs. This means the next generation of vectors is born already infected.
  • An example of transovarial transmission is Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks, the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever.

Explanation of other options:

Cyclo-propagative - Plasmodium in mosquitoes (Option B): In cyclo-propagative transmission, the infectious agent undergoes changes in form as well as multiplication within the vector. In the case of malaria, Plasmodium parasites enter the mosquito during a blood meal, undergo sexual reproduction and sporogony, producing numerous sporozoites.

Cyclo-developmental - Wuchereria bancrofti in mosquitoes (Option C): In cyclo-developmental transmission, the pathogen undergoes development but no multiplication within the vector. Wuchereria bancrofti, which causes filariasis, follows this pattern. After a mosquito ingests microfilariae from an infected host, they develop into infective larvae without multiplying and are then transmitted to another person during a subsequent bite.

Propagative - Yersinia pestis in rat fleas (Option D): The transmission of Yersinia pestis, the plague bacilli by rat fleas is an example of propagative biological transmission, where the pathogen multiplies within the vector but does not undergo any developmental changes. In this case, the bacteria proliferate in the flea's gut and are transmitted to humans during subsequent bites.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by fomites?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Measles is primarily spread by airborne transmission via respiratory droplets and aerosols, not through fomites.

Other airborne diseases:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Influenza
  • Chicken pox
  • Measles
  • Q fever
  • Covi 19
  • Fomites are contaminated inanimate objects other than food and water that can transfer infectious agents from an infected person to a healthy one.
  • The fomites play an important role in indirect infection.
  • Examples include clothes, towels, utensils, toys, and medical instruments. Diseases spread via fomites include diphtheria, typhoid, bacillary dysentery, hepatitis A, and eye or skin infections.

Explanation of other options:

Diphtheria (Option A): Diphtheria, caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, is primarily spread via respiratory droplets from coughing or sneezing. However, the bacteria can also survive on contaminated surfaces - fomites, making indirect transmission through contact with mucous membranes possible.

Typhoid (Option C): Typhoid fever, caused by Salmonella Typhi, is primarily transmitted via the feco-oral route through contaminated food or water. However, the bacteria can also survive on fomites, especially in areas with poor sanitation. Transmission may occur if contaminated objects are touched and then brought into contact with the mouth.

Hepatitis A (Option D): Hepatitis A, caused by the hepatitis A virus (HAV), is mainly transmitted via the feco-oral route, typically through contaminated food or water. However, HAV can also survive on fomites, allowing indirect transmission if contaminated objects come into contact with the mouth.

questions.text: Which of the following best exemplifies an indirect mode of disease transmission?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An indirect mode of transmission refers to the transfer of infectious agents from an infected individual or reservoir to a susceptible host via an intermediary, such as contaminated objects, surfaces, or vectors.
  • Hands are the most common medium by which pathogenic agents are transferred to food from the skin, nose, bowel, etc, as well as from other foods.
  • The transmission takes place both directly (hand-to-mouth) and indirectly.

Modes of transmission:

questions.text: Which of the following disease pairs correctly identifies conditions where humans act as dead-end hosts?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Man is considered a dead-end host when the pathogen infects the human but cannot exit the body to infect others, thereby halting further transmission.
  • This is seen in diseases like rabies, tetanus, bubonic plague and trichinosis, where humans do not serve as a source of infection to others due to the absence of an effective portal of exit.
  • In tetanus, humans acquire the infection from environmental spores (Clostridium tetani) and do not transmit it to others.
  • While in rabies, transmission is typically from animals to humans via bites, but human-to-human transmission is extremely rare.
  • Hence, in both conditions, humans are considered dead-end hosts, not contributing to the pathogen's transmission cycle.
  • Both measles and yellow fever viruses can be transmitted from person to person, and infected individuals can contribute to the spread of these diseases to others. Therefore, humans are not dead-end hosts for measles or yellow fever. (Option A, B, C ruled out)

choices.text: Time gap between onset of disease in primary and secondary cases
Time required for 50% of cases to develop disease after exposure
Time between exposure and development of first symptom
Time between exposure and diagnosis of disease

questions.text: Which of the following best defines the median incubation period of a disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The median incubation period is defined as the time required for 50% of individuals exposed to a pathogen to develop symptoms of the disease.

  • An infection becomes apparent only after a certain incubation period, which is defined as the time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and the appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease. (Option C ruled out)
  • During the incubation period, the infectious agent undergoes multiplication in the host.
  • The median incubation period is defined as the time required for 50 per cent of the cases to occur following exposure.
  • It is a measure of the central tendency of the distribution of incubation periods for a particular disease.
  • The incubation period is of fundamental importance in epidemiological studies, as it helps:
    • Tracing the source of infection and contacts
    • Determine period of surveillance (quarantine)
    • Aids in immunisation
    • Identification of point source or propagated epidemics
    • Prognosis evaluation

Explanation of other options:

Time gap between onset of disease in primary and secondary cases (Option A): A primary case is followed by 2 or 3 secondary cases within a short time. The gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called the serial interval. It thus measures the gap in time between successive cases in a chain of transmission.

Time between disease initiation and diagnosis (Option D): This refers to the latent period. The latent period has been defined as the period from disease initiation to disease detection. The term latent period is used in non-infectious diseases as the equivalent of the incubation period in infectious diseases.

questions.text: The gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The serial interval is the time between the onset of symptoms in a primary case and the onset of symptoms in a secondary case that was infected by the primary case.
  • It measures the gap in time between successive cases in a chain of transmission.
  • It helps in understanding the dynamics of disease transmission and is crucial in epidemiological investigations and modelling.

Explanation of other options:

Lead time (Option A): Lead time refers to the period between the detection of a disease through screening or diagnostic tests and the onset of symptoms or clinical presentation. It is often used in the context of early detection or screening programs.

Generation time (Option B): It is defined as the interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host. In general, generation time is roughly equal to the incubation period.

Latent period (Option D): Latent period has been defined as the period from disease initiation to disease detection.

choices.text: Interval between contamination of fomites and infection of host
Interval between receipt of infection by host and maximum infectivity of the same host
Interval between onset of index case and secondary case
Interval between infection and first sign or symptom

questions.text: Generation time refers to which of the following intervals in the natural history of infectious diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Generation time is the interval between the acquisition of infection by a host and the point of maximum infectivity.
  • It is a key parameter in understanding disease transmission dynamics and helps estimate how quickly an infection can spread within a population.
  • This period is critical in identifying when an infected individual is most likely to transmit the disease to others.

Explanation of other options:

Interval between contamination of fomites and infection of the host (Option A): This interval is not referred to as the generation time. It may be relevant in understanding the transmission dynamics of diseases spread through fomites, but it does not specifically define the concept of generation time.

Interval between the onset of the index case and the secondary case (Option C): This is referred to as the serial interval. The serial interval measures the time between the onset of symptoms in a primary case and the onset of symptoms in a secondary case infected by the primary case.

Interval between infection and first sign or symptom (Option D): This defines the incubation period, which represents the time between exposure to a pathogen and the onset of symptoms of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following does not classify as a quarantine measure used for the containment of infectious diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Isolation is not a type of quarantine.
  • Isolation is the separation of infected persons or animals during their period of communicability to prevent transmission of the infectious agent to susceptible individuals.
  • Quarantine is defined as the limitation of the freedom of movement of persons or domestic animals exposed to a communicable disease for a period not longer than the longest usual incubation period of the disease, to prevent effective contact with those not so exposed.
  • Quarantine may be:
    • Absolute quarantine: Involves the strict isolation of individuals who are either confirmed or suspected to be infected with a contagious disease.
    • Modified quarantine: A selective partial limitation of freedom of movement, such as the exclusion of children from school.
    • Segregation: Segregation involves separating individuals who are infected with a contagious disease from those who are healthy. e.g., removal of susceptible children to homes of immune persons.

questions.text: In a community, there are usually 40-50 reported cases of dengue every week. This week, there were 48 reported cases. This would be classified as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The weekly reporting of 40-50 dengue cases reflects the normal pattern for the community, indicating that dengue is consistently present and thus classified as endemic.
  • Endemic refers to the constant presence and/or usual prevalence of a disease or infectious agent within a geographic area or population group.

Explanation of other options:

Epidemic (Option A): An epidemic refers to the sudden increase in the number of cases of a disease above what is normally expected in a population or geographic area. It typically involves a larger-than-expected number of cases occurring in a relatively short period.

Sporadic (Option C): Sporadic refers to occurrences of a disease that are infrequent and irregular. These cases typically happen unpredictably and are scattered throughout time and space. With 48 reported cases in a week and the usual range being 40-50 cases, the occurrence of dengue in this community does not appear to be sporadic.

Outbreak (Option D): Outbreak carries the same definition of epidemic, but is often used for a more limited geographic area. It may involve a sudden increase in the number of cases in a specific geographic area or within a specific population group.

choices.text: No new cases are reported for one incubation period of the disease
Surveillance over one year reports no cases
Six months of data show no reported cases
No new cases are reported for a duration equal to twice the incubation period of the disease

questions.text: An area is officially declared free from an epidemic when:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An area is officially declared free from an epidemic when no new cases are reported for a period equal to at least twice the maximum incubation period of the disease.
  • This ensures sufficient time to account for delayed transmission and helps prevent premature declaration, offering a more reliable safeguard against recurrence.

questions.text: A public health surveillance report records the following disease trends in a community: Based on the number of cases, which of the following correctly classifies these disease patterns? Disease X: 42 reported cases last week and 43 this week Disease Y: 2 reported cases last week and 42 this week Disease Z: 6 reported cases last year and 1 case this year
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Disease X shows almost a consistent number of cases each week - 42 last week, 43 this week, which is characteristic of an endemic disease. Endemic disease remains constantly present at a predictable rate in a population.
  • Disease Y displays a sharp increase in reported cases - from 2 last week to 42 this week, indicating an epidemic, which refers to a sudden rise in the number of cases above the expected level in a defined area.
  • Disease Z, with very few cases - 6 last year, 1 this year, reflects a sporadic pattern, meaning it occurs infrequently and irregularly.

questions.text: The 12-by-12 initiative was launched in India to address which of the following public health problems?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The 12-by-12 initiative was launched in 2007 to ensure that every child would have a haemoglobin of 12 g/dL by the age of 12 years by 2012.
  • It is specifically aimed at addressing
  • Children between the age group of 10-14 years were screened, and if haemoglobin was found below 12 g/dL, weekly IFA supplementation was provided.
  • It also comprised public awareness creation, correction of dietary pattern and control of worm infestation through periodic deworming along with weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation.
  • Weekly Iron and Folic Acid supplementation is provided to all adolescent boys and girls from classes 6 to 12 enrolled in government, government-aided, and municipal schools, as well as to out-of-school adolescent girls.

Explanation of other options:

Polio (Option B): The 12-by-12 initiative is not related to polio. Polio has been addressed through initiatives like the Global Polio Eradication and Pulse Polio Program, which successfully led to India being declared polio-free in 2014. As of 25th Feb 2012, India was removed from the list of polio-endemic countries, and on 27th March 2014, India was certified as a polio-free country.

Tuberculosis (Option C): The Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) and National TB Elimination Programme are the key programs in India to tackle TB. There are also global efforts to control and eliminate tuberculosis, such as the World Health Organisation's End TB Strategy.

Fluorosis (Option D): Fluorosis is a condition caused by excessive intake of fluoride, leading to dental and skeletal fluorosis. The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Fluorosis (NPPCF) was implemented to address the problem of Fluorosis.

Reference Anaemia Mukt Bharat :: National Health Mission (nhm.gov.in)

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the WHO STEPwise approach to non-communicable disease risk factor surveillance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Psychological assessments are not included in the standard WHO STEPwise framework.

  • The WHO STEPwise approach to Surveillance (STEPS) is a systematic method for collecting, analysing, and disseminating data related to noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) and their risk factors.
  • The methodology prescribes three steps:
    • Questionnaire
    • Physical measurements
    • Biochemical measurements
  • The questionnaires collect household-level sociodemographic details, individual medical histories related to major noncommunicable diseases (NCDs), and information on risk behaviours such as tobacco use, alcohol consumption, unhealthy diet, and physical inactivity.
  • Physical measurements are used to assess overweight and obesity, and increased blood pressure.
  • Biochemical measurements involve blood and urine sampling to measure raised blood glucose, cholesterol, high-density lipids, and sodium and creatinine levels.
  • The core topics covered by most surveys are demographic, health status and health behaviours.
  • These provide data on socio-economic risk factors and metabolic, nutritional and lifestyle risk factors.
  • It helps countries develop and implement NCD prevention and control programs by providing standardised tools and protocols for data collection.

questions.text: A soldier presents with fever, rash sparing the palms and soles, and myalgia. Several members of the battalion have a history of louse infestation. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features in this scenario are characteristic of epidemic typhus, which is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The history of louse infestation in the battalion strongly supports this diagnosis, as body lice are the primary vectors responsible for transmitting this infection.

Epidemic typhus:

  • Epidemic or louse-borne typhus was, in the past, the most formidable disease caused by rickettsiae.
  • It was the cause of devastating epidemics among military and refugee populations and in areas affected by famine.
  • The infection is transmitted from man to man by the infected louse (P. corporis and P. capitis).
  • The louse gets infected by feeding on an infectious patient during the febrile stage. The organisms multiply in the cells lining the intestinal tract of the louse and begin to appear in 3 to 5 days in the louse's faeces.
  • Man acquires the disease not by the bite of the louse, but:
    • By scratching and inoculating himself with the infected louse faeces
    • By crushing an infected louse on his person
    • Possibly by inhalation of infected louse faeces or dust.

Explanation of other options:

Rickettsia conorii (Option B): Rickettsia conorii causes Indian tick typhus, transmitted by tick bites. Patients usually have a history of tick exposure and may develop an eschar at the bite site. The rash characteristically begins on the wrists and ankles and spreads centripetally, often involving the palms and soles.

Rickettsia typhi (Option C): Rickettsia typhi is the causative organism of murine typhus, which is transmitted to humans primarily through the bite of infected fleas. The clinical presentation of murine typhus may include fever, rash, and myalgia, but the absence of rash on the palms and soles is not consistent with murine typhus.

Rickettsia akari (Option D): Rickettsia akari causes rickettsialpox, transmitted by mites from rodents. It presents with fever, eschar, and a vesicular rash.

choices.text: Transmission may occur via the nosocomial route

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Ebola virus disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Ebola virus is not transmitted by mosquitoes. It spreads primarily through direct contact with infected bodily fluids such as blood, saliva, urine, vomit, and faeces or via contact with contaminated objects and surfaces.

Ebola virus disease:

  • Previously known as Ebola hemorrhagic fever, it s a deadly hemorrhagic fever, caused by the Ebola virus, a member of the Filoviridae family. (Option C ruled out)
  • The natural reservoir is a bat, and the disease is mostly seen in Africa due to bushmeat.
  • Ebola has an incubation period of 2-21 days, and is not infectious during this period.
  • The virus is primarily transmitted through direct contact with the blood, organs, body secretions or other body fluids of infected animals.
  • The viruses can even survive in semen and eye fluids.

Symptoms:

  • The illness is characterised by a sudden onset of fever, intense weakness, muscle pain, headache, sore throat, vomiting, diarrhoea, rash, impaired kidney and liver functions.
  • In some cases, affected people may bleed both internally and externally.

Treatment:

  • Treatment for Ebola virus disease is only supportive, involving oral rehydration therapy or intravenous fluids to maintain hydration and electrolyte balance.
  • Prevention includes properly cooking meat, wearing protective clothing, practising regular hand hygiene, and handling patient samples with strict biosafety precautions.
  • The available vaccine, rVSV-ZEBOV (recombinant vesicular stomatitis virus-Zaire Ebola virus vaccine), is used for outbreak control.

Explanation of other options:

Transmission may occur via the nosocomial route (Option A): While direct contact with infected body fluids is the primary mode of transmission for Ebola, nosocomial transmission can occur through contaminated medical equipment, inadequate infection control practices, or contact with infected individuals in healthcare settings.

Humans are accidental dead-end hosts (Option D): Ebola virus primarily circulates in animal reservoirs, particularly fruit bats. Humans can become infected with Ebola through contact with infected animals or through human-to-human transmission, but they are considered dead-end hosts because sustained human-to-human transmission is not typical. Ebola outbreaks often start with zoonotic transmission from animals to humans, and human outbreaks usually do not result in sustained transmission beyond a limited number of generations of cases.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases has the highest mortality once clinical symptoms appear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rabies is a vaccine-preventable, zoonotic, viral disease of the central nervous system transmitted through the saliva of infected animals, usually via bites.
  • Once clinical symptoms develop, it is almost invariably fatal, with a mortality rate approaching 100%, making it one of the deadliest infectious diseases.
  • Dog bites and scratches cause 99% of the human rabies cases.
  • However, rabies deaths are preventable with prompt post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) by stopping the virus from reaching the central nervous system. PEP consists of thorough wound washing, administration of a course of human rabies vaccine and, when indicated, rabies immunoglobulins.

Explanation of other options:

H1N1 Influenza (Option A): While H1N1 influenza, commonly known as swine flu, can lead to severe illness and even death, especially in vulnerable populations such as the elderly, young children, and individuals with underlying health conditions, the mortality rate is generally lower than that of rabies. With prompt medical care and antiviral treatment, many patients with H1N1 influenza can recover.

Nipah Virus (Option B): Nipah virus infection is a zoonotic disease transmitted from animals to humans, most often through contact with fruit bats or their excreta. It can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis, with a mortality rate ranging from 40% to 70%, depending on the outbreak and the quality of healthcare in affected regions.

Ebola (Option D): Ebola virus disease is a severe and often deadly illness in humans. The average Ebola disease case fatality rate is around 50%. The case fatality rates during outbreaks have varied widely, ranging from around 25% to over 90%. While Ebola virus disease can have high mortality rates, especially in resource-limited settings, some patients do survive with appropriate medical care and supportive treatment.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being bitten on the leg by a stray dog. He has not received a prior rabies vaccination. Post-exposure prophylaxis with rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin is advised. Which of the following statements regarding rabies immunoglobulin is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All of the rabies immunoglobulin, or as much as anatomically possible (but avoiding possible compartment syndrome), should be administered into or around the wound site or sites. The remaining immunoglobulin, if any, should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.

  • Rabies immunoglobulin for passive immunisation is administered only once, preferably at, or as soon as possible after, the initiation of post-exposure vaccination.
  • Beyond the seventh day after the first dose, rabies immunoglobulin is not indicated because an active antibody response to the rabies vaccine is presumed to have occurred. Rabies vaccine is a cell-derived or embryonated egg-based vaccine. (Option C ruled out)
  • The dose of human rabies immunoglobulin is 20 IU/kg body weight; for equine immunoglobulin and F (ab')2 products, it is 40 IU/kg body weight. (Option B ruled out)
  • Most of the new equine immunoglobulin preparations are potent, highly purified, safe and considerably less expensive than human rabies immunoglobulin.
  • However, they are of heterologous origin and carry a small risk of anaphylaxis
  • Human Rabies Immunoglobulin (HRIG) is the preferred choice due to its lower risk of adverse reactions compared to purified equine RIG. However, if HRIG is not available, purified equine RIG can be used as an alternative. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following diseases has documented endogenous transmission in India?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Endogenous transmission refers to the occurrence of a disease within a particular geographical area or population without an external source of infection.
  • CCHF, Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic fever, is a tick-borne viral disease that is endemic to certain parts of India, particularly in rural areas where livestock is raised.
  • Endogenous transmission of CCHF occurs within these regions through the bites of infected ticks or contact with blood or tissues of infected animals.
  • The vector for Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is the hard tick, Hyalomma species.
  • The disease presents with both external and internal haemorrhages, and death may occur due to shock.
  • It has been reported in parts of India, including Gujarat and Odisha.

Explanation of other options:

Yellow Fever (Option A): Yellow fever is not endemic in India, and reported cases are usually imported from endemic regions like Africa and South America. There is no endogenous transmission of yellow fever within India.

Ebola virus (Option C): Ebola virus disease is also not endemic to India. Outbreaks occur mainly in Central and West Africa, with sporadic cases in other regions linked to travel-related exposure.

Hendra virus (Option D): Hendra virus is primarily found in Australia and is transmitted to humans from horses. It is not endemic to India, and there have been no reports of endogenous transmission of Hendra virus in the country.
